metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 943 and 980 to 989 of 1973

facts.text: State of Rajasthan proposed to acquire land for the planned development of the city of Jaipur.
Notification under section 4 of the Rajasthan Land Acquisition Act, 1953 issued on 13 May 1960, published in Rajasthan Gazette on 9 June 1960.
No objection was made under section 5A of the Act.
Notification under section 6 of the Act published on 11 May 1961.
Notices under section 9 of the Act issued on 18 July 1961.
63 persons including the predecessor-in-title of the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 943 of 1973 filed claims.
Award under the Act made on 9 January 1964.
Award amended on 9 July 1964 because of certain transactions of sale of portions of the land.
Writ Petitions filed on 23 January 1970 challenging notifications dated 13 May 1960 and 3 May 1961 under sections 4 and 6, and notices dated 18 July 1961 under section 9.
Rajasthan High Court judgment dated 12 April 1973 dismissing writs on ground of inordinate delay and rejecting merits of challenges on discrimination and low acquisition price.
Appeals by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellants guilty of inordinate delay in challenging notifications under sections 4, 6 and 9.
Validity of land acquisition proceedings on ground of discrimination.
Whether land acquired at negligible price to be sold at exorbitant price by Improvement Trust.

petitioner_arguments.text: Challenged validity of notifications dated 13 May 1960 and 3 May 1961 under sections 4 and 6, and notices under section 9 dated 18 July 1961.
Land being acquired at negligible price and same would be sold at exorbitant price by Improvement Trust.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellants guilty of inordinate delay; no need to go into merits if delay ground succeeds.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Aflatoon Ors. v. Lt. Governor of Delhi Ors.

court_reasoning.text: High Court rightly held appellants guilty of inordinate delay; appellants came to court nine years after declaration under section 6.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Challenge to section 4 and 6 notifications should be made within reasonable time thereafter; delay puts premium on dilatory tactics.

court_reasoning.text: In Aflatoon case, petitioners waited till after section 9 notice to challenge earlier notifications.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Length of delay important due to nature of acts done in interval based on notifications.

court_reasoning.text: Land acquisition proceedings commence with section 4 notification, followed by 5A objections, then section 6 declaration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Any challenge to section 4 or 6 must be prompt.

holdings.text: Writs dismissed by High Court on ground of delay upheld; no merit in other contentions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Aflatoon Ors. v. Lt. Governor of Delhi Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held that challenging section 4 and 6 notifications after completion of proceedings due to dilatory tactics not permitted.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Land Acquisition Act, 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Notifications, declarations, objections, claims and award under these provisions; challenge to their validity dismissed on delay.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals by special leave from Rajasthan High Court judgment, upholding dismissal of writs on ground of inordinate delay in challenging land acquisition notifications.

key_quotes.text: if persons allowed the Government to complete the acquisition proceedings on the basis that the notification under section 4 and the declaration under 6 were valid and then attacked the notification on grounds which were available to them at the time when the notification was published it would be putting a premium on dilatory tactics.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on laches in land acquisition challenges.

key_quotes.text: The appellants came to Court nine years after the declaration under section 6 of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights extent of delay justifying dismissal.
